course.subject: PHYS
course.name: Honors General Physics I
course.description: This course is a more in-depth version of PHYS 1112. It is intended to provide a solid foundation to students who wish to take more advanced physics courses in the future. Key topics include motions and Newton’s Laws, work and energy, conservation of energy and momentum, rotation, rigid body, simple harmonic and damped oscillations, forced oscillations, standing waves and sound waves, kinetic theory and the laws of thermodynamics. Students without the prerequisite may seek instructor’s approval for enrolling in the course. For students under the 4-year degree only.
course.prerequisites: (Level 5* or above in HKDSE 1/2x Physics OR in HKDSE 1x Physics) AND (Level 5 or above in HKDSE Mathematics Extended Module M1/M2)
course.exclusions: PHYS 1111, PHYS 1112

reviews.author: BABA
reviews.comment_content:
This course focuses heavily on problem solving and less on exploring theoretical concepts in detail. It moves at an extremely fast pace, and would be extremely hard to follow if you are not already aware of all the concepts being taught. I would suggest that only the following students take up this course:

-Have studied and are more than familiar with the content, and have used calculus thoroughly in problem solving in high school.

-Are genuinely interested in challenging themselves and are not here to get an easy A.

-Think they possess above average intelligence.

These are the necessary AND sufficient criteria for joining this course.

(Attendance isn't a requirement. So if you are an Olympiad gold medalist, go chill in the...library)
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof CHAN can be best described as being mediocre.

He had one flaw the existence of which, even though quite common, turned out to be disappointing.
He would randomly go about working on a problem without explaining the intent behind each step. I emphasize this, he would explain the 'reasoning', but not the 'intent' behind each step.

The teaching assistant barely made his presence felt except on days on which he would collect the written HW.
reviews.comment_grading:
Getting more than mean in the midterms and finals will get you an A. Prof CHAN even mentions that at the very beginning.

I got mean marks in the midterms and finals and was quite careless about the HW, and didn't even submit it once. I eventually got a B+.

If you are looking for a certain A, join PHYS1112.
reviews.comment_workload:
Every week, students are required to do ONLINE and WRITTEN homework.

The written homework is quite fun and challenging, only if you are interested in physics and problem solving in general. It comprises of 2-3 long problems and would take around 2-15 hours depending on the level of difficulty (Yes, I once spent 15 hours solving one single problem, still couldn't do it and eventually decided to take help from the teaching assistant). But to be honest, it was something I personally looked forward to every week.

The online homework is incredibly irritating. It involves more calculations than an ordinary calculator does in its entire lifespan. Holy s*** I'm getting angry just thinking about it. It takes around 2-6 hours depending on your level of frustration.

reviews.comment_workload:
One homework per week, 9-14 questions per week.
10 homework in total, with no HW in first week and the week during midterm. Also, there is an optional HW11 for you to do revision.
They are the difficult questions from the textbook, with given quantities randomly generated. Technically you can find the answers online, but it is meaningless to do so. If you just want good grade, just go back to PHYS1112. PHYS1312 is for you to challenge yourself. Getting good grade in PHYS1112 should be easier. There is no LQ in 1112, and you don't need to prepare yourselves for LQ.
Also, if you never really do those homework, you will no nothing and easily fuck up in exams.
I have never record how long I took to do them, but you need to expect you need at least 3-4 hours per week unless you are very talented. If you are not good in physics, you might need more. I would recommend you to plan your time and don't try to do them all within one day.
Each homework will be released 2 weeks before the deadline.

For tutorials, no attendance is needed. You might do the questions at home and read the solutions by yourselves, or even not do them. Not much workload. Again, not doing any exercise at all will make you fuck up in exams. In fact, one question appeared in final exam is similar to a tutorial question.

Another main source of workload is to do revision for exams, which could be quite exhausting.

reviews.author: Pluto12138
reviews.title: SURVIVAL GUIDE for common students in an Honour Course
reviews.comment_content:
A starting point for the study of general physics. The framework and major topics are pretty much the same as PHYS1112, but it contains more mathematical induction, reasoning, and some more complex physics models. Key topics include:
motions and Newton’s Laws, pseudo force,
change of framework, Coriolis force in rotating frame of reference (only mentioned, without mathematical reasoning)，
work and energy,
conservation of energy and momentum,
rotation, rigid body (important; accounted for many midterm and final scores),
gravity and celestial motion (mainly concepts, limited discussion into mathematical details of orbits and so on),
simple harmonic motion,
damped oscillations, forced oscillations, resonance (again, only concepts, not too much mathematical analysis),
standing waves and sound waves,
kinetic theory and the laws of thermodynamics,
Entropy and heat machines.

Continuum mechanics, though it appears in the textbook, is not discussed in this semester’s lectures.

Calculus is used in many sections of the course, but only for basic things like integrating, approximating, and solving very simple differential equations. People aren’t expected to tackle complex integration or compute higher order differential equations. Applying simple things dextrously is the true problem here.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Leung is a good instructor. He is passionate and humorous in the classes and gives detailed discussion and proof for the class contents. You and your "loved one" will suffer a lot from his examples, lol. If he thinks some of the points are not adequately discussed in the lecture, he will make supplement videos for people to watch, though these are optional. He is also very willing to answer students’ questions after class, and you can find him during his office hours.

Tutorial attendance is strongly recommended (ignore this if you are an IPHO medalist). It introduces some problem-solving techniques that are not necessarily included in the classes. It will give you a taste of utilising calculus dexterously and equip you with some skills that are important for the exam.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is pretty good. Very wide A and A+ range.
15% homework (via Pearson Mastering Physics, must pay ~300$ HKD for the access, discuss later)
40% midterm.
45% final.

In this semester, the content of the midterm and final do not overlap (which is why the midterm takes up a large proportion of the grading scheme, do take it seriously). Chapters covered in the middle won’t be tested explicitly in the final, though some of that knowledge will be used in some sections of the questions.

There will be a 3% deduction for each wrong attempt in the homework, and you will lose access to the problem if you input the wrong answer six times or press the "request an answer" button.
So, try not to guess the answer and treat each attempt carefully. Many students get ~14%+ for their homework.

There are some very talented students from Hong Kong, the Mainland, and other parts of the world in the class. Some of them have general physics training from their high school or may even have IPHO, ICHO experience. It can be tough to get into the top notch of the class.

But the grading scheme is very generous. I think I eventually ranked only ~8-9 in the class of 65, but I still somehow managed to get an A+. It is said that getting above the mean will ensure people an A range grade, and the worst possible grade, if you attended the exams, will be a B-. Fair (and generous) enough.
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too heavy but are from easy. Your weekly routine includes:
A ~10 question homework, including 1-2 challenging questions. ~2-3 hours if you understand most of the content.
A tutorial with 2–3 questions, one or two of which may be hard,
Two lectures, with RVC recordings available.
 
The difficulty of the exams, especially the long questions, is close to the hard questions in homework and tutorials. The bad thing here is that you don’t have many past papers to work on (like 1112). People may find themselves ill-prepared for the long questions due to a lack of exercise and some conceptual multiple-choice problems, that are not emphasised in the assignments. Therefore, it is a good idea to go through lecture notes carefully before exams and make good use of homework and tutorials.

reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. LEUNG, Pak Wo is a humorous as well as professional teacher. He explains the concepts in a vivid way and derives the formulas detailedly. Some experiments will also be presented to make students better understand the knowledge.

There will be an assignment for 2 or 3 lectures. Each assignment has about 10 problems. Usually it takes 2-3 hours to finish all of them. Some problems would be easy to solve while some are a little bit difficult. Discussing the problems you can't solve with your classmates might help a lot.
If you want to master the knowledge of general physics I, you may spend more time handling the concepts and formulas on your own.

reviews.author: Sarah0501
reviews.comment_content: The course covers some basic information about dynamics(3/4) and thermology(1/4). A little simple but very practical.
reviews.comment_teaching: LEUNG, Pak Wo is really a nice guy and very good at teaching. His classes are always interesting and he can make abstract knowledge representational.
reviews.comment_grading: As honor general physics, most students got good grades. About mean scores means A range.
reviews.comment_workload: On average, there is one homework about ten questions a week. Understanding the knowledge also take a little time after class but won't take too much. Generally, spending about 3 to 4 hours a week and a little more time before the examination will guarantee a good grade.

reviews.author: ccccccc
reviews.title: good course
reviews.comment_content:
The content is very good. I talked about mechanics.
This course is a more in-depth version of PHYS 1112. It is intended to provide a solid foundation to students who wish to take more advanced physics courses in the future.

Motions and Newton's laws

reviews.comment_teaching: He is a very good teacher. He will teach us a lot of knowledge, and others are very good.
reviews.comment_grading: nice
reviews.comment_workload: great

reviews.author: Ray-_-
reviews.title: Very good professor
reviews.comment_content:
The course is at an extremely fast pace, the content is very rich and a lot of concepts need to be digested. It mainly goes through the things you have learnt in Secondary school or High school with a deeper concept and calculation. It also touched on Thermodynamics which you may not have learnt.
The content mainly focuses on:
1) Units, Physical Quantities, and Vectors.
2) Motion Along  a Straight Line
3) Motion in Two or Three Dimensions
4) Newton's Laws of Motion
5) Applying Newton's Law
6) Work and Kinetic Energy

reviews.comment_teaching:
One of the best Professors in this sem.
Prof. JO is very good at teaching, he does not use any PowerPoint in his class and directly wrote the virtual blackboard.
His accent is clear, he cares for his students and welcomes any questions.
reviews.comment_grading:
The exam is not that hard as I expected and makes sense.
The grading is generous compared to other courses, I think if you get mean on everything, you would probably get something like b+ or something.
reviews.comment_workload:
Extremely heavy, I have to revise for at least 5 more hours every week for the new concepts and extra challenging HW, mastering physics is only a cup of tea compared to the challenging homework.

I have to do extra materials (Cambridge reference book) to have better concepts and a better understanding of the unfamiliar topics.

I have devoted at least 7 days, studying 12 hours a day for the exam.

reviews.author: Anacreon
reviews.comment_content:
I think the content is ok. STRONGLY suggest to learn some basic calculus before. (differentiate, integrate, and you'll find it useful to have some knowledge about solving differential equations)
Classmates asked many interesting questions. Really learnt a lot .
reviews.comment_teaching:
f2f is good! Professor was very patient.
However, online mode is not that satisfactory. I need to spend many time later on in order to better digest.
reviews.comment_grading:
I think my grade is reasonable because I didn't do well in my final exam.
However, I got nearly full marks or full marks in all the assignments and midterm exam.
B+
reviews.comment_workload:
It depends. If you are dedicated to physics, you might find the workload very heavy.
It's not very time-consuming to finish the homework if you're familiar with basic concepts and are clear about how to use them.
However, if you want to understand the concepts well, you need to look for many reference resources. This might be EXTREMELY time-consuming somehow...

reviews.author: tdhvl
reviews.comment_content:
Like PHYS 1112, this course covers simple topics in classical mechanics and thermodynamics but focus more on problem solving and requires a certain background in Calculus. If you have participated in some Physics Olympiads in High School, then the materials in this course should not be difficult for you and probably you will have already known them before. If not, then the content should be rewarding for you if you work hard.
Professor Chan has mentioned at the beginning that this course is only suitable for those who are interested in challenging themselves or have a passion of solving hard exercises instead of an easy student life. If you are not, then you should consider taking PHYS 1112.
If you are a non-local student, you will have to submit a Requisites Waiver and come to the first lecture to fill the sign up sheet. After that, Prof. Chan will waive the requisites for you.
reviews.comment_teaching:
In my opinion, Prof. Chan is very dedicated. Besides PowerPoint slides, he writes his own notes during the lectures and explain carefully the example and the exercises. He also performs many experiments during the lectures to demonstrate the contents that he just taught. In each class, there are some iPRS questions to test the understanding of the students, but it is not used for grading purpose.
Prof. Chan also spend time to answer the students' questions after the lectures.
reviews.comment_grading:
You will be graded according to your performance in Homework, Midterm and Final exams. The grading scheme is:
Homework 15%
Midterm 35%
Finals 50%
Like other Honors courses, many people get good grades since they are all talented. The percentage of A-range grades are better than PHYS 1112. However, if you want to get an A+, you will have to compete with some extremely smart students. Some of them may be even IPhO medalists. Usually, about 5-10 people get the A+ grades if they performed very well in this course.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is heavy. There is a written assignment each week that you have to solve some long problems and it takes much time. Also, the homework includes online exercises through MasteringPhysics. These exercises were taken from the textbook. Therefore, they are easier compared to the written one, you just have to compute carefully.
However, if you have participated in Physics Olympiads, then the workload of this course should not be heavy for you. Since Prof. Chan does not take attendance, you can even skip the classes and only come to the lecture to submit your written homework if you are self-confident enough.

reviews.author: Fpn
reviews.title: Honors General Physics I
reviews.comment_content: Phys 1312 is a thorough version of Phys 1112. If you want to learn deeper than Phys 1112, this class is the right choice for you. The powerpoint slides are almost the same as in Phys 1112, but the instructor explains a bit more.
reviews.comment_teaching: The instructor and TA are both really kind and helpful. The teaching is great, the instructor performs interesting experiment each week related to the topic in front of the class. He tried to make the topic not to be boring. Non-graded IPRS quizzes also tests our understanding. During the tutorial class, he explained about physics problems that might be found in the upcoming homework (almost similar idea).
reviews.comment_grading: The percentage to get A or A+ is much greater than it is in Phys 1112 (Phys 1312 is also bell-curved). However, a lot of mainland students and students that have experience with physics olympiad are in this class. So make sure you're ready if you enroll in this course.
reviews.comment_workload: We have Masteringphysics homework (online) which is also taken by students in Phys 1112. But we are also given written homework of about 1-3 essay problems per week. But don't worry if you have enough math skills and if you come to each lecture and tutorial.

reviews.author: trash
reviews.comment_content:
The content includes mechanics, wave motion and a bit heat and gases.

Some overlap with the HKDSE syllabus, but most of the syllabus is quite new to a normal local student. The homework and teaching notes are quite difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
His voice is not attractive, though it is quite clear.

He likes to do demonstrations during class. Quite interesting
reviews.comment_grading:
above mean <1 SD = A-

He is being very lenient.

However, most of the time you will compete with NDS, which are very great in Physics.
reviews.comment_workload:
Heavy af, hw every week

But it is a good practice for students who are not self motivated.

reviews.author: Stefan
reviews.comment_content: The overall content of this course is good. It covers the basics of physics. Basically, it is a more in-depth version of high school physics (mechanics and thermodynamics). Remember to study hard for the midterm and final exam because it wouldn't be so easy.
reviews.comment_teaching: In my opinion, the professor explains everything clearly but the pacing is a bit too fast in my opinion. Sometimes the pacing is a bit too fast, but still fine. The professor mainly uses powerpoint ppt and writes the equations uring his tablet.
reviews.comment_grading: Because this course is curved, be careful if you don't have any background in physics. There are a lot of mainland students and physics olympiad medalist. I ended up with a good grade, so I think the grading is good. The instructor will explain the grading in the first lecture, so make sure to come to the first class if you want to take this course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is fine. Two essay problems every week and mastering physics homework (online). Actually, I don't really like mastering physics because we need to buy the physical book. Everything you need for the homework will be explained during the lecture, so the book is not so useful in fact.

reviews.author: 7K

Key topics include motions and Newton’s Laws, work and energy, conservation of energy and momentum, rotation, rigid body, simple harmonic and damped oscillations, forced oscillations, standing waves and sound waves, kinetic theory and the laws of thermodynamics. Students without the prerequisite may seek instructor’s approval for enrolling in the course. For students under the 4-year degree only.

reviews.author: Andy Chen
reviews.comment_content:
As a general physics course, the content is basically about general physics, introducing from fundamental units to thermodynamics. If you are not familiar with topics included in general physics, just randomly pick up a textbook and read the catalog, which will help you to get a more concrete picture.
However, instead of topics going to be taught, the more important thing is how deep the professor will dig into these topics and how hard it will eventually become since this is an "Honor" course. Here I can boldly tell you, it is only a little bit harder than the textbook used in class, which is written by Young and Freedman. Still, one need to consider two things before taking this course. First, the professor quite focuses on the proof of physics laws in comparison with other courses. Second, the exams are actually even harder than the content taught in class. In fact, the difficulty of exams is similar to that of weekly hand-written assignments.
reviews.comment_teaching: CHAN, Ho Bun is a great instructor. Fluent English. Clear presentation. However, the thing I admire him the most is that he not only tells you results but explains the reasons behind them. If he does some trick to solve the problem or to prove some physics law, he will try to tell you why this trick works and the intention of it. This is quite uncommon among other instructors but so important since it prevents one from memorizing the steps. Instead, it helps one to develop one's thinking.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is fair.
Homework 15%. Midterm 35%. Final 50%.
If your grade is above mean, you get at least A-.
Probably the top 5 to 10 students will get A+, which I am not sure. However, I ranked about 10 in the midterm and about 5 in the final, at last getting A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy.
Two assignments every week. One is the web homework and the other is hand-written. The web homework is easier but annoying sometimes since the numbers are complicated even though you can use a calculator. The hand-written one is harder and it is usually composed of two problems. Sometimes you need to prove something. Process is required.

reviews.author: twinkle
reviews.title: a foundation course for research in physics
reviews.comment_content:

reviews.comment_teaching: Acceptable, but sometimes his explanation does not make sense. Then you have to study the relevant content by yourself and search for some other materials. The professor will give some written notes each class for a supplement of his lecture notes. Since his handwriting is not good, you really need to concentrate in each class in order to understand what he wrote... Tutorials are necessary as he will also give lectures in the tutorials.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade. The statistics he provided in the first lecture showed that about 50% of the students can get A range and most of the rest can get B range. You can get a decent grade as long as you make some effort after class. But A+ is relatively difficult since there are many students who have learned something about physics competition before. Of course, if you are one of them, then A+ may be not that difficult for you.
Grading scheme: 15%Homework+35%Midterm+50%final
Me: homework 14.5/15
midterm above mean ~0.4 sd
final above mean ~1 sd
Finally got A. I think the grading is really good!
reviews.comment_workload: A little bit heavy. There were both online homework in masteringphysics and written homework containing 2 or 3 long questions. The online homework was relatively easy since it just helped you understand the concepts and get familiar with the formulas. But the long questions, especially those related to dynamics of rigid bodies and angular momentum, were really challenging. You have think carefully and arduously to get correct answers and give you explanation carefully. A little carelessness will make you below mean!

reviews.author: hi come find me
reviews.title: Interesting Common Course
reviews.comment_content:
There are a lot of topics to be covered in this course. I have some friends studying PHYS in HKU and basically what I learnt from this course are more or less the same as what he has learnt in 2 years.

Unlike ordinary HKDSE PHYS, you cannot simply plug the equations like v=u+at. In this course, it involves a lot more calculus. From Mechanics to Wave, more intensive syllabus is covered like the parallel axis theorem and damping.
reviews.comment_teaching: Prof. Chan has the best spoken English ability in the Science School I think. Although he did not really explain very well the intent and intuition, his steps and other explanations are kinda useful. Yet, don't expect to ask via email cuz his answers are kinda short there. TA is good tho (should be Patrick).
reviews.comment_grading: I got both below mean in the midterm and final exam but I did all the homework and online assignment and finally got a B-.
reviews.comment_workload: A lot of workload and the HW are indeed quite challenging. The online Pearson Exercise you have to do very carefully. Like you got wrong for once then the mark you get for that question will be deducted by 10% After 6 times, you will receive 0 mark. Every week you have one written and one online assignment. And you really need to understand in order to answer the questions.

reviews.author: Guess who I am
reviews.title: A course I enjoyed
reviews.comment_content: This course is a kind of expansion of PHYS1112 and the main topics covered by these two courses are overall same, except that PHYS1312 focuses more on formula deduction. If you are curious about how the formula come out rather than simply remembering them, PHYS1312 is worthy to try.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think the professor is trying his best to usher us into fantastic physics world. His passion to physics is undoubted, and I believe he brings this passion to teaching as well. Before each class, we can get access to PPT in Canvas, and professor uses the pad to write down notes and projects on screen, and releases notes on Canvas after class. So on class you can more focus on catching on the content rather than rushing to finish your own note.
reviews.comment_grading: The honor course's grading scheme is always more mercy than ordinary course. What I mean "mercy" here, is that the proportion of A range and B range is larger than ordinary course, rather than you can get a better grade in honor courses if pay out same effort as your would do in ordinary courses, as you need to compete against your strong classmates.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is proper. Every week has regular homework to do and it can be divided into two parts - online work and paper work. Online work is same to PHYS1112, while paper work needs your more in-depth understanding on the knowledge. Sometimes paper work can be quite time-consuming but more helpful.

reviews.author: Small_Potato
reviews.title: Very fun course for students who want to learn more about physics, but watch out for IRE gods :o)
reviews.comment_content: A more advanced version of PHYS1112. Some people may find PHYS1112 too easy but PHYS1312 too difficult, so it is up to you to decide which path you want to take. The difficulty goes up gradually during the course and the finals was very challenging, even though some students can still achieve 49/50 which was unbelievable. You learn about basic mechanics (linear motion, simple harmonic motion, gravitation...), rotational motion (moment of inertia, rotational energy, angular momentum...) and thermodynamics (heat engine, 0th/1st/2nd law of thermodynamics, heat exchange...), just like PHYS1112. However, calculus knowledge is a prerequisite and there are additional techniques you have to learn.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Very good teaching. Prof Chan writes his own notes during the lesson and teaches stuff out of the powerpoint. He shows the steps very clearly so you can follow them easier. There are some demos in lessons and he even inhaled Helium one time. There are iPRS questions every lesson which allows you to check your own understanding.

Prof Chan also takes time after lessons to answer students' queries and he points out the common mistakes in students' homework.
reviews.comment_grading:
The mean last spring (forgot which semester?) was B+/A-, and the minimum grade was B-. You can still obtain a rather okay grade even if you do not perform that well in your midterm and finals. There are some very smart mainland students and IRE students who always score a high mark in the exams, so make sure you always push yourself to do better in order to catch up. Some people here are even IPhO gold medalists. It can be very discouraging once you see the score distribution of the midterms and finals, as some people will always attain a crazy high score. Some of my friends kind of regretted taking this course as they would have most likely achieved better grades with PHYS1112.

Grading policy:
Homework 15%
Midterm 35%
Finals 50%

Homework: Around 99% score
Midterm: Above mean 1.36 SD
Finals: Above mean 0.47 SD
Final grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is pretty heavy. You have a piece of written homework and online homework almost each week, and each of them takes a bit of time... you can expect yourself to spend at least 1.5 hours in total each week. Some questions may be very challenging, but the exam questions will be on the next level. Prof Chan encourages us to spend more time on the homework by giving us final answers for checking sometimes.

Doing your homework can be very frustrating, since MasteringPhysics deducts you 10% instead of 3% as in PHYS1112 for each wrong attempt, and some written questions require very very lengthy and tedious calculations. But if you like physics, I guess doing the questions will be fun in a way.

For midterms and finals, there are both MCs and LQs, as compared to only MCs in PHYS1112. At first you will be confused at the long duration of the midterm, but once you get the paper, you will have the answer to that question.

reviews.author: K.Ahmed
reviews.title: A more in-depth version of a course than PHYS 1112. This course demands strong foundation in calculus and physics.
reviews.comment_content: The content is similar to PHYS 1112. However it demands more from students. In addition to all the knowledge from PHYS 1112, students have to integrate calculus into the computations. Thus the content becomes much harder. Instead of solving generic questions, students have to solve fundamental proof-type questions with very less numbers and more variables. This is a very nice course as students get to learn Physics in very nice depth.
reviews.comment_teaching: In my opinion, Professor Chan, Ho Bun is a very organized professor. His lectures are easy to follow. He goes over assignments after they are handed in. Moreover he gives us tips for the challenging assignment and examination questions. He gives students encouragement even if they aren't doing too well. He does call on students to answer questions in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
Above mean is A- or above.
I got about 1 sd lower than mean in mid-term as I didn't put in much effort into assignments and revision.
I did better for finals and got about 0.5 sd above mean.
The questions in the mid-terms and finals are just extended versions of questions from written assignments. Thus it's important to thoroughly understand how to do your assignments.
(Should do all assignments on your own. Without referring to other student's work or copying online.)
Overall I was pulled down due to the mid-term.
At the end I got a B.

Assignments are very important. With a class full of hardworking students. Students can't afford to lose free marks. Moreover the assignments will prepare students for the examinations.
reviews.comment_workload:
1 written assignment a week.
There are usually at max 2 challenging questions with less than 15 lines of computations each (sometimes only 3 lines).
However they require quite a lot of time to think of solution on your own. This can become quite stressful.

(Can take up to 1 whole day for average/below average students. Or can take just 10 minutes if you understand everything.)

1 online assignment each week.
A lot of intermediate level questions. However in total become quite time consuming.

Be prepared to devote quite a lot of time to the course if you would like to get an A.

reviews.author: mcreng
reviews.title: One of the best courses
reviews.comment_content:
Syllabus:
- Physical quantities, dimensional analysis, vectors
- Motion in 2D
- Newton'w laws
- Work and Energy
- Momentum, impulse and collision
- Dynamics of rigid bodies
- Angular momentum
- Gravitation
- Periodic motion
- Wave motion and sound
- Temperature
- Thermal properties of matter
- First & Second law of thermodyanmics

The syllabus contains more contents than PHYS1112 and they are more in-depth, you would love to take this course if you want to have a greater understanding in physics (esp. in motion, wave & heat)

The exam is more harsh than the standard one, apart from MCs (which are the only question type in PHYS1112), we have long questions, with difficulties similar to the written homework.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Prof. Chan is one of the best professors I have met in HKUST. He is very passionate in teaching and is willing to answer any sort of questions after lecture. We typically keep him for 30 minutes more after lecture to ask our question :P
One thing I would like to mention is the atmosphere of the classroom, among classmates we sometimes talk about the written problems and questions we have during lectures, and truthfully this is the only course yet that I have the opportunity to experience such a nice learning atmosphere. It might be true that all honour courses have a similar atmosphere as well.
reviews.comment_grading: Attached are the histograms for both the mid-term and final exams. From score-grade conversion point of view, this is an awesome course, I got an A- even I went below 0.5 SD in mid-term and hit mean in final. Yet, whether you can keep being at mean in both exams are another question. Prof. Chan mentioned in his first lecture that at least half of the class would get an A-range grade.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is high in this course, the reason being the difficult assignments. In this course, we would need to finish both MasteringPhysics (this one for PHYS1112) and written assignments. The difficulty for the former one is quite easy in my humble opinion, they are more or less equal to those in PHYS1112. Yet, the written homework are very challenging, I typically need a whole weekend to figure out the solution, and sometimes I need to discuss with my classmates for a better solution.

reviews.author: IRE Guy
reviews.title: Good Course, But Watch Out For Really Smart Students
reviews.comment_content:
PHYS 1312 basically covers the same topics of PHYS 1112, with a bit more in-depth discussion in topics like simple harmonic motion, waves, etc. You will need a lot more calculus in proving stuff in 1312 than 1112, and questions you are going to encounter are proof-based.

The first half semester will cover basic mechanics learnt in DSE/ high school with some differentiation and integration. You will learn some new stuff in the second half semester such as simple harmonic motion, wave equation, Kepler's Laws of Planetary Motion, gravitation and thermodynamics. Personally, I found those latter topics more difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor Chan is a REALLY nice professor and we can tell he is really into teaching his fellow students. He is good at drawing pictures and diagrams to illustrate theorems. He also stayed behind to answer a bunch of questions from the hard-working Chinese.
reviews.comment_grading:
Although I did not attain a satisfactory grade in 1312, I have to say 1312 has a much better grading scheme than 1112. If I were in 1112, I bet I would get a much lower grade. If you want to attain a good grade here, you have to out-smart a lot of genius here in 1312, ranging from Physics Olympiad medalists to top scorers in Gao Kao of mainland China.
We have PRS but professor Chan said they won't be included in our grades.
reviews.comment_workload:
It depends. If you love to solve physics long problems with no numbers at all, then you might handle 1312. Otherwise, you will have to struggle every week just because you probably need to spend days to solve 1-2 difficult homework problems, not to mention that tricky online short problems of Masteringphysics.
If you are one of those genius I mentioned, you can consider this light workload and skip all the lectures while still managing an A+ just like what the IRE genius had done.

reviews.author: mindy_vm6
reviews.comment_content: The content that was taught in the course is basically the same as PHYS 1112 but exam and homework is harder.

reviews.comment_workload: The workload is quite heavy. Online and hand-writing homework have to be hand in every Thursday.

reviews.author: Davy
reviews.title: Good Professor
reviews.comment_content: This course is about basic idea of dynamics , sound and heat. Compared to phys 1112, their content are similar, but phys 1312's exams has some difficult long questions.
reviews.comment_teaching: I think the professor is excellent. Even the tutorial section he taught in person. And he did many demonstrations this term, which were very interesting and inspiring.
reviews.comment_grading: I think this course's grade is good if you devote your time to it. Almost half of the students get A range.
reviews.comment_workload: Because it's an honor course, its workload is a little big. But I think the homework really help us to prepare for the exam.

reviews.author: ey2016
reviews.comment_content: It is a good course for those who want to take physics as  their major in the future.There are not too many new topics,but the professor will teach you some new approaches to solving physics problem.It is recommended to those who do not join any physics Olympics but want to study physics in the future .
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is good at teaching and he is willing to answer any students' questions. Sometimes he stays behind after the lectures and answers students' question.
reviews.comment_grading: The grading is reasonable.if you take it serious and you will not do too bad.But it is quite difficult to get  A or above if you have no experience in Physics Olympics.

reviews.title: Biggest regret in my first semester in UST
reviews.comment_content:
Intro mechanics and a little bit of thermodynamics.

As the course introduction suggest, some of the content might get a little bit deeper than the normal general physics course, but nothing is really difficult, and the whole course follows closely to the textbook (that being said, the course will finish that whole thick book in about 3 month, so be careful about the pace you study).

Here's my sincere advice:

You might have already learnt most of the material being taught in this course, but even so please be sure you at least review a little as the course goes.

Personally, this is like my 3rd or 4th time studying these introductory stuff, and I choose to do so simply for the sake of getting an easy A. So I must confess, I was just too unmotivated to even bother about studying. But apparently I am not familiar enough with those intro things to have all of them still staying in my head after two years, adding to that, some of the material was covered a little deeper than what I used to learn the first time. And that really did got me. It ended up, you know, I got nowhere near an A, and I really regret it.

So, do work hard if you choose PHYS1312.
reviews.comment_teaching:
I can tell Prof. Chan really did try his best to teach, and he did try to give a satisfactory answer to every single question asked by the student.

But still, honestly, the lecture can get fairly boring, and I just never think teaching physics with PowerPoint is a good idea.
reviews.comment_grading:
The professor has explicitly said that every one got above mean should get some kind of A's.

But consider, anyone choose to be in this "honors" physics course must be somewhat good in physics, so the mean can be quite high and most people will be on it. So it is really not that easy to get a high grade and the grading is really not that generous as many people suggested (consider how easily will you get an A if you choose PHYS1112 instead) (but still not too bad) .

As others had mentioned, the exams are divided into 2 parts, MC and free responses. The free response questions are similar in difficulty with the homework problems, and none of them are particularly difficult. Though if you are not too used to long exams, it can get quite intense (Well... I guess most local or mainland students will not have this problem, but I myself did performed fairly poorly on the final simply because I didn't have enough stamina to concentrate for that long that day...).

I merely managed to get on mean, and I got B+.
reviews.comment_workload:
One written homework (typically two long problems in one set) and one problem set on Mastering Physics every week.

The written part can get a little bit challenging sometime, but fairly doable. Though I suggest to kill them all early in the week, being a deadline fighter and found yourself got struck in physics problems is no fun. (from my own experience of being a deadline fighter essentially every week from week 3...)

Also, you might want to be aware of how quickly you can solve these homework problems, as you have to solve a series of them under time pressure in exams.

Overall, the written problems are quite interesting and valuable to do, but in contrast the Mastering Physics part tended to be tedious and annoying.

Collectively, the workload can get kinda heavy given that if you do all the homework yourself and spend the time to go over the material taught in class. But like I said, be sure you take the workload if you want a good grade.
